questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drug causes least weight gain? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ziprasidone

 

Ziprasidone is known to cause less weight gain compared to many other antipsychotics, making it a more suitable option for an obese patient concerned about further weight gain. Clozapine and olanzapine, in particular, are associated with a higher risk of significant weight gain and metabolic changes. Chlorpromazine, while potentially causing weight gain, is generally not as strongly linked to this side effect as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic. These drugs can cause weight gain, though chlorpromazine is not as strongly associated with weight gain as some atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic known for causing significant weight gain, along with other metabolic effects.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another atypical antipsychotic that is frequently associated with substantial weight gain and metabolic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a lower risk of weight gain. It is considered more weight-neutral compared to other atypical antipsychotics like clozapine and olanzapine.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

 

While it is commonly believed that femoral hernias are the most frequent type of hernia in females, this is not the case. The most common type of hernia in both males and females is the inguinal hernia, specifically the indirect inguinal hernia.

 

Inguinal hernias occur due to a weakness in the abdominal wall and the presence of a natural opening, the deep inguinal ring. Indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through this deep ring, are particularly common. Although femoral hernias are more commonly seen in women than in men, their overall incidence is much lower compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal: This type of hernia is less common than indirect inguinal hernias and occurs due to weakness in the floor of the inguinal canal. It is not the most common type in females.

 

Option C. Femoral: Although more common in women than in men, femoral hernias have a much lower overall incidence compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Obturator: This is a rare type of hernia and is not commonly seen in the general population, including females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of hernia in females, as in males, is the indirect inguinal hernia. Despite the misconception, femoral hernias, though more common in women than men, are less frequent overall.

questions.text: From which of the following does the posterior part of the tongue develop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Hypobranchial eminence

 

 

Explanation:

 

The posterior one-third of the tongue develops from the hypobranchial eminence (also called the copula of His). This midline swelling is formed in relation to the medial ends of the second, third, and fourth pharyngeal arches. The cranial part of the hypobranchial eminence, specifically related to the third arch, forms the posterior one-third of the tongue. This explains why this portion of the tongue is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which is the nerve of the third arch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lingual swelling - This is incorrect because the lingual swellings (from the first pharyngeal arch) contribute to the formation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not the posterior part. These swellings fuse with each other and possibly with the tuberculum impar to form the oral part of the tongue.

 

Option B) Tuberculum impar - This is incorrect because the tuberculum impar is a midline swelling that appears between the lingual swellings and contributes to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not the posterior part. Some sources suggest it may not make a significant contribution at all.

 

Option D) Tongue bud - This is incorrect because "tongue bud" is not a standard term used in the embryological development of the tongue. The tongue develops from the lingual swellings, tuberculum impar, and hypobranchial eminence, not from a structure called the tongue bud.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The tongue has dual embryological origins - the anterior two-thirds develops from first arch derivatives (lingual swellings and possibly tuberculum impar), while the posterior one-third develops from the hypobranchial eminence associated with the third pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability. The diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output

 

In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect

 

  • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)

 

Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect

 

  • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect

 

  • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy from Rajasthan weighing 50 kg is diagnosed with mixed P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria. What is the appropriate treatment regimen on day 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In the treatment of malaria, the choice of drugs and regimen depends on the type of malaria (whether it's P. vivax, P. falciparum, or mixed infection) and the geographic location due to different strains' drug resistance profiles. For mixed infections involving P. vivax and P. falciparum, the treatment typically includes a combination of drugs targeting both species.

 

For P. vivax malaria, chloroquine is generally used, followed by primaquine for 14 days to achieve a radical cure by eliminating hypnozoites and preventing relapse. However, in mixed infections and P. falciparum malaria, the treatment regimen includes an Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT). Specifically, in regions like Rajasthan, ACT comprises artesunate plus sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine.

 

On day 2 of treatment, sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (which is given only on day 1) has already been administered, so the treatment continues with artesunate and primaquine.

 

Primaquine is dosed at 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days in cases of P. vivax, and the dosage calculated for this patient (weighing 50 kg) is 15 mg/day

 

(0.25 mg/kg × 50 kg = 12.5 mg, rounded to the nearest available tablet strength).

 

The correct regimen on day 2 includes Artesunate (to continue targeting the malaria parasites) and Primaquine (for radical cure and to prevent relapse), specifically at the dosage of 2.5 mg per tablet (6 tablets totaling 15 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malaria Treatment Regimens:

questions.text: Identify the correct labelling of the ulcer in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edge

 

Parts of an ulcer are clearly defined:

 

 

Edge: Junction between floor and skin 

 

Floor: Visible surface of ulcer that can be seen

 

Base: Tissue on which floor rests (not visible but can be palpated)

 

Margin: Where edge merges with surrounding healthy skin

 

Key characteristics:

 

Edge provides important diagnostic clues:

 

  • Punched out in trophic ulcer
  • Undermined in tuberculous ulcer
  • Everted in malignant ulcer
  • Sloping in healing ulcer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edge of an ulcer is the junction between floor and surrounding skin, and its characteristics provide important diagnostic clues.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old patient presented with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was performed, and the reports are as follows: (FMGE JULY 2024)

 

  • Opening pressure – elevated
  • Appearance – cloudy
  • Cell count – 80 (70% PMNs)
  • Sugar – 35 mg/dL
  • Protein – 200 mg/dL

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Bacterial Meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of meningitis: fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis from the lumbar puncture provides several key clues:

 

  • Elevated opening pressure, which is common in bacterial meningitis.
  • Cloudy appearance of the CSF, indicating a high number of cells or increased protein.
  • Cell count of 80 with 70% polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs), which is highly indicative of bacterial infection as it typically shows a neutrophilic predominance.
  • Low glucose level (35 mg/dL) and elevated protein level (200 mg/dL), which are consistent with bacterial meningitis due to the consumption of glucose by bacteria and increased protein from the inflammatory process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Viral Meningitis: Viral meningitis usually presents with a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose levels. This does not match the neutrophil predominance and low glucose levels seen in this case.

 

Option C. TB Meningitis: TB meningitis often shows a lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, significantly elevated protein levels, and moderately low glucose levels. While the glucose and protein levels could fit, the neutrophil predominance makes TB meningitis less likely.

 

Option D. Fungal Meningitis: Fungal meningitis typically presents with a mixed or lymphocytic predominance in the CSF, elevated protein, and low glucose. Neutrophilic predominance is not characteristic of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute bacterial meningitis is characterized by elevated opening pressure, cloudy CSF, a high cell count with neutrophilic predominance, low glucose, and elevated protein levels in the CSF.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, having lost her newborn, is producing breast milk, which risks developing into a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which drug can prevent this complication? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the primary goal is to suppress lactation to prevent milk stasis and subsequent breast abscess formation. Lactation is driven by the hormone prolactin, which is released from the anterior pituitary gland. To suppress milk production, prolactin release must be inhibited.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors, which in turn inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland. By reducing prolactin levels, cabergoline effectively suppresses lactation, thereby reducing the risk of milk stasis and breast abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: This drug is a progesterone receptor antagonist primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: This is an antipsychotic medication that blocks dopamine D2 receptors. Blocking dopamine receptors would actually increase prolactin levels and promote milk production, thus potentially worsening the risk of milk stasis and abscess.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: This drug is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is sometimes used as a galactagogue (to promote milk production). Like chlorpromazine, it would increase prolactin levels and thus is not suitable for preventing lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline, a dopamine receptor agonist, is used to suppress lactation by inhibiting prolactin secretion, thereby preventing complications like milk stasis and breast abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following thumb muscles is innervated by two different nerves? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B) Flexor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation:

 

Flexor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence that has a dual nerve supply. Its superficial head is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, while its deep head may receive innervation from the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This dual innervation makes it unique among the thumb muscles. The muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the trapezium, and inserts into the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It functions to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Flexor pollicis longus - This is a deep muscle of the anterior compartment of the forearm, not a thumb muscle proper. It is solely innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve).
  • Option C. Adductor pollicis - Located in the palm, this muscle is exclusively supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve (the "graveyard of the ulnar nerve").
  • Option D. Opponens pollicis - This is a thenar muscle that is exclusively innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It facilitates the opposition movement of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexor pollicis brevis is unique among thumb muscles due to its dual innervation pattern - the superficial head by the median nerve and the deep head by the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the social history taking, she mentions that she has started engaging in certain behaviors and rituals that align with her new community after recently moving to a different country. What is the term for this type of behavior acquisition? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Socialization

 

Explanation:

 

  • Learning and try to adapt to new community. This is known as Socialization
  • Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and adopt the norms, values, and behaviors appropriate to their society. 
  • Socialization is key in helping individuals function as members of their society, and it involves learning the language, norms, and rituals of the community.
  • This term directly applies to the scenario described, as the woman is adopting behaviors that align with her new community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Custom: This term refers to a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time. Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting

 

Option B. Culture: Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired. Culture is a broader term that includes knowledge, belief systems, art, morals, laws, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by individuals as members of society.

 

Option D. Mores: These are the moral norms, manners, or customs that are considered important for the welfare of a community and are enforced by social disapproval or formal sanctions if violated. Mores are a subset of social norms that include strong moral connotations and are seen as foundational to societal welfare.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"Socialization" best captures the process the woman is undergoing as she adopts the practices of her new community.

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

 

The image shown is a cross-sectional CT scan of the head, particularly focusing on the orbit which is highlighting an abnormal finding adjacent to the orbit, which is indicative of a subperiosteal abscess.

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is forms between the orbit's periosteum (a dense layer of vascular connective tissue covering the bones) and the bone. It is usually a complication of sinusitis, especially ethmoid sinusitis, which can lead to infection spreading to the orbital area. On the CT scan, it appears as a localized bulge or collection adjacent to the bone, as shown in the image. This is consistent with the marking on the image indicating a crescent-shaped fluid collection that deforms the normal contour of the orbit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cellulitis: This condition involves inflammation and infection of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. However, orbital cellulitis typically involves more diffuse inflammation that would visibly impact more of the orbital tissue on imaging.

 

Option C. Preseptal Cellulitis: This infection involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, without affecting the orbit itself. The condition would not typically show significant findings behind the orbital septum on a CT scan, as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Sinusitis Only: While sinusitis, the inflammation of the sinus linings, can lead to complications such as a subperiosteal abscess, sinusitis itself would typically show thickened sinus linings and air-fluid levels within the sinus cavities on a CT scan, without necessarily involving the orbit unless complicated by adjacent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.

questions.text: Where does the maximum water absorption occur within the renal tubules? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCT

 

The Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) is the site where the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the nephron. Approximately 60-65% of the filtered water is reabsorbed in the PCT. This reabsorption is largely due to the active transport of sodium ions, which creates an osmotic gradient that drives water reabsorption.

 

The PCT is highly efficient in reclaiming water, electrolytes, and other essential nutrients from the filtrate, ensuring that the body retains vital substances while excreting waste products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DCT (Distal Convoluted Tubule):  While the DCT does participate in water reabsorption, it does so to a much lesser extent compared to the PCT. The DCT is more involved in the fine-tuning of sodium, potassium, and pH balance.

 

Option C. Loop of Henle:  The Loop of Henle, particularly the descending limb, is permeable to water and contributes to water reabsorption. However, the amount of water reabsorbed here is significantly less than in the PCT.

 

Option D. Collecting duct: The collecting duct is involved in the final concentration of urine and reabsorption of water under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). While it plays a crucial role in water reabsorption, the total volume reabsorbed here is less than in the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) is the site of maximum water absorption within the renal tubules, reabsorbing about 60-65% of the filtered water.

choices.text: Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament

questions.text: In which of the following meniscal tears will meniscectomy be a more suitable option than meniscal repair? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Tears in the inner zone

 

Meniscal tears in the inner zone (inner 2/3rd) are treated by excision (meniscectomy) rather than repair. This is because the inner 2/3rd of the meniscus is avascular, which means it has poor healing potential. In contrast, the peripheral 1/3rd of the meniscus receives blood supply and therefore can be repaired when torn since it has better healing potential.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tears in the outer zone - This is incorrect because the outer zone (peripheral 1/3rd) is vascular and has good healing potential, making it suitable for meniscal repair rather than meniscectomy.

 

Option B. Tears in the middle zone - This is partially incorrect. While the middle zone has less vascularity than the outer zone, tears at the junction of the middle and outer zones may still be amenable to repair depending on specific characteristics of the tear.

 

Option D. Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament - This is incorrect because this area is in the peripheral region of the meniscus which receives adequate blood supply, making repair a more suitable option than meniscectomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meniscectomy is preferred for tears in the inner avascular 2/3rd of the meniscus due to poor healing potential, while tears in the vascular peripheral 1/3rd are better treated with repair.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

 

Lignocaine 2% (also known as lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for cataract surgery. It provides effective and rapid onset of anesthesia, making it ideal for this type of procedure. Lignocaine is typically used for infiltration anesthesia, which involves injecting the anesthetic around the eye to block nerve impulses.

 

Types of Local Anesthesia:

 

  • Infiltrating Type: This involves injecting the anesthetic directly into the tissue to numb a specific area.
  • Topical: Applied directly to the surface of the skin or mucous membranes. Best drug is proparacain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine 0.5%:  While bupivacaine can be used in ophthalmic surgery, it's generally reserved for cases where longer-lasting anesthesia is required. It's not the first choice for routine cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Prilocaine 0.5%:  Prilocaine is sometimes used in dental procedures but is not commonly used in ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option D. Ropivacaine 0.05%:  Ropivacaine is used in various surgical procedures but is not typically the first choice for cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: In which phase of the sexual cycle does premature ejaculation occur? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Orgasmic phase

 

Explanation:


Premature ejaculation occurs during the orgasmic phase of the sexual response cycle. This phase is characterized by reflexive pelvic muscle contractions and is the shortest of all the phases. Premature ejaculation refers to the occurrence of ejaculation earlier than desired, either before or shortly after sexual penetration, and it can result in significant distress. It happens specifically during the orgasmic phase because this is the phase in which ejaculation is physiologically triggered. The rapid arrival at orgasm, without adequate time spent in the earlier phases (excitement and plateau), is what defines premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Excitement phase: This initial phase involves increased blood flow to genital tissues, erection of the penis, and initial secretion of lubricating fluids. Ejaculation does not occur during this early preparatory phase.
  • Option B. Plateau phase: This represents the period of heightened sexual tension before orgasm, with continued vasocongestion and muscle tension building. Ejaculation has not yet occurred at this stage.
  • Option D. Resolution phase: This phase follows orgasm and is characterized by a return to the non-aroused state, with detumescence and relaxation. Ejaculation has already occurred before entering this phase.

 

Educational objective:


Premature ejaculation is defined as ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired during the orgasmic phase, before or shortly after penetration, and with minimal stimulation.

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Thurston-Holland's sign is seen in Salter Harris Type: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. II

 

  • The Thurston-Holland's sign refers to the triangular metaphyseal fragment that remains attached to the epiphysis in Salter-Harris Type II fractures. 
  • This metaphyseal fragment is a key radiographic finding that helps distinguish Type II from other types of epiphyseal injuries. 

 

 

  • Type II is one of the most common epiphyseal injuries and has a generally good prognosis because the growth plate is not significantly damaged.
  • The fracture goes through the growth plate and then extends above into the metaphysis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A  I: In Type I fractures, there is a clean separation through the growth plate without any metaphyseal or epiphyseal fragment. The fracture line runs completely through the physis with no metaphyseal fragment. Often difficult to see on X-ray unless there's widening of the growth plate. So Thurston-Holland's sign is absent.

 

Option C  III: This type involves a fracture through the growth plate that extends into the epiphysis (joint surface). The fracture does not involve the metaphysis, so there is no metaphyseal fragment to produce Thurston-Holland's sign.

 

Option D V: This represents a crush injury to the growth plate that may not be visible on initial radiographs. It causes compression of the physis and has no visible fracture line or metaphyseal fragment, thus no Thurston-Holland's sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thurston-Holland's sign refers specifically to the metaphyseal fragment seen in Salter-Harris Type II fractures and serves as an important radiographic marker for identifying this type of injury, which has a good prognosis compared to types III, IV, and V.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INSM

 

Intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers are specifically located within the nucleus of the cell, unlike cytoplasmic or membranous markers.

 

INSM (Insulinoma Associated Protein 1) is a novel intranuclear marker used for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell carcinoma of the lung, medullary thyroid cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma, and paraganglioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option B. NCAM: Incorrect because it is a membranous marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option C. Synaptophysin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

questions.text: The membrane covering an omphalocele is primarily formed by which of the following embryonic structures? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

An omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines or other abdominal organs protrude outside of the body through the umbilical ring but are covered by a protective membrane. This membrane consists of multiple layers:

 

  • Inner Layer: The inner layer of the covering is the peritoneum, which lines the abdominal cavity.
  • Middle Layer: Wharton’s jelly, a gelatinous substance, is located between the peritoneum and the outer covering.
  • Outer Layer: The outermost layer of the covering is derived from the amnion, which is part of the fetal membrane surrounding the developing fetus.

 

Thus, the amnion forms the outermost layer covering the omphalocele, providing protection to the protruding organs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer that gives rise to internal structures like the lining of the gastrointestinal tract, not the covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, and connective tissues but does not specifically contribute to the external covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is another fetal membrane that participates in placental formation but does not directly form the covering of the omphalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The outer covering of an omphalocele is derived from the amnion, with the peritoneum lining the inner surface and Wharton’s jelly situated between the peritoenum and outer covering.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

choices.text: Air in lung after normal expiration
Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration
Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration
Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration

questions.text: Which of the following best defines vital capacity? (NEET pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration

 

Explanation:


Vital capacity (VC) is defined as the maximum amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. It represents the sum of tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In healthy adults, VC typically measures around 3.5 L, though this varies based on factors like gender, age, and body size.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Air in lung after normal expiration This definition describes Functional Residual Capacity (FRC), which equals ERV + RV (approximately 2.5 L). FRC represents the volume remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration.
  • Option b. Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration This describes Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) only, which is approximately 1 L. ERV is just one component of vital capacity.
  • Option d. Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration This defines Total Lung Capacity (TLC), which includes VC plus the residual volume (RV). TLC = IRV + TV + ERV + RV (approximately 5 L).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be expelled from the lungs after a maximum inspiration, representing the sum of IRV, TV, and ERV, and is a key measurement in pulmonary function testing.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Achalasia is a condition characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia), weight loss, and regurgitation. The typical radiological finding in achalasia is a smooth narrowing and gradual tapering at the lower esophagus, often described as a "bird's beak" appearance. The presence of dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis (bad breath) in a young patient, along with the image showing smooth narrowing, points strongly towards achalasia. The halitosis, though mentioned, is often not a significant feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca esophagus: This condition would typically present with progressive dysphagia rather than the intermittent dysphagia seen in achalasia. Halitosis is not commonly associated with esophageal cancer, and the radiological appearance would differ, showing irregular narrowing rather than the smooth tapering seen in achalasia.

 

Option C. Corrosive stricture: This would likely present with a history of corrosive ingestion and would show irregular, scarred, and narrowed areas of the esophagus, not the smooth tapering characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option D. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition can present with dysphagia and halitosis due to the trapping of food in the diverticulum, but the radiological appearance is quite distinct, typically showing a pouch at the pharyngoesophageal junction. The image provided does not suggest this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient, along with imaging showing smooth narrowing and gradual tapering, is highly suggestive of achalasia.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

 

Explanation:

 

Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenger's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.

 

Option C. Lombard's Test: This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.

 

Option D. Erhardt's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: A male patient suffers a trauma and is being brought to the emergency room of a hospital. Since he needs an emergency lifesaving transfusion, which of the following can be safely transfused in him?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) O negative

 

In emergency situations where a lifesaving transfusion is needed, and there is no time to determine the patient's blood type, O negative blood is considered the universal donor and can be safely transfused to any patient. This is because O negative blood does not have any A, B, or Rh antigens on the surface of the red blood cells, minimizing the risk of an adverse reaction.

 

However, it is important to note that O negative blood is often in short supply. In extremely critical situations, such as with an older male or a postmenopausal female, or when O negative blood is not available, O positive blood may be used as an alternative. O positive blood can be safely transfused to males and females who are not of childbearing age, as the presence of Rh antigen can cause issues in future pregnancies for females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive: A positive blood type contains A and Rh antigens and can only be safely transfused to individuals with A positive, AB positive, or compatible types. It is not a universal donor.

 

Option B. AB negative: AB negative blood can only be given to AB negative or AB positive recipients due to the presence of both A and B antigens. It is also not a universal donor.

 

Option D. O positive: While O positive blood can be given in critical situations, it is not the first choice for universal emergency transfusions due to the presence of Rh antigen, which can cause complications in Rh-negative individuals, especially females of childbearing age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency transfusion situations where blood type is unknown, O negative blood is the safest option due to its lack of A, B, and Rh antigens, making it universally compatible.

questions.text: Delusions are commonly observed in all of the following conditions, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Conversion Disorder

 

Explanation: 

 

Conversion Disorder (also called Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder or Dissociative Neurological Symptom Disorder in ICD-11) is characterized by neurological symptoms like paralysis, blindness, or seizures that cannot be explained by medical conditions. Importantly, delusions are not a feature of conversion disorder. Conversion disorder involves a psychological stressor that manifests as physical symptoms, but the patient does not have false, fixed beliefs (delusions) about their condition.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Schizophrenia (Incorrect): Delusions are core symptoms of schizophrenia. According to the DSM-5 criteria, delusions are one of the characteristic positive symptoms required for diagnosis.
  • Option B. Depression (Incorrect): Delusions can develop in a patient with depression. These may include delusions of guilt, nihilistic delusions (e.g., believing internal organs have rotted), or delusions of poverty.
  • Option C. Dementia (Incorrect): Delusions can occur in dementia, particularly in moderate to severe stages. These are usually transient and less complex than those seen in primary psychotic disorders. Common delusions in dementia include persecutory delusions, delusions of theft, or misidentification delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusions are common features of psychotic disorders like schizophrenia, severe mood disorders with psychotic features (including depression), and neurocognitive disorders like dementia. Conversion disorder, however, is characterized by unexplained neurological symptoms without the presence of delusions, as it belongs to the somatic symptom/dissociative disorder category rather than the psychotic spectrum.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoroscopy

 

The image provided is a still from a video fluoroscopy study, which is essentially a continuous X-ray video that allows the visualization of dynamic processes in real time, such as swallowing. This technique is used for examining the movement of the pharynx and esophagus. Although the image might appear to be from a barium swallow study, the key distinguishing factor is that it shows only the pharynx, which aligns more with a fluoroscopy study rather than a traditional barium swallow.

 

In a barium swallow, the entire esophagus is visualized, whereas fluoroscopy focuses more on the pharyngeal phase of swallowing. Therefore, even though both fluoroscopy and barium swallow are correct interpretations of the image, fluoroscopy is the more precise answer since it captures the pharyngeal motion observed in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium swallow: A barium swallow involves the patient swallowing barium to coat the esophagus, making it visible on X-rays. However, this image specifically shows the pharyngeal phase, which is more consistent with fluoroscopy rather than a complete barium swallow study.

 

Option C. Acid ingestion: Acid ingestion refers to the damage to the esophagus or stomach lining due to acid, which would present differently on imaging. This condition does not correspond to the observed fluoroscopy of swallowing.

 

Option D. Alkali ingestion: Similar to acid ingestion, alkali ingestion would show chemical burns or strictures but would not be directly visualized in a swallowing motion study like fluoroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray imaging technique used to visualize the motion of the pharynx and esophagus during swallowing. It provides real-time assessment, unlike a static barium swallow.

choices.text: Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother
Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm

questions.text: Ventouse is contra-indicated in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preterm

 

Ventouse (vacuum extraction) is contraindicated in preterm deliveries due to the increased risk of neonatal complications. The head of a preterm baby is more vulnerable to injury, and the use of vacuum can lead to severe complications such as neurological damage, cephalohematoma, or skull fractures. This is because the vacuum exerts force on the baby’s head, which is particularly fragile in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother: This is not an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery. In fact, vacuum extraction is often used when there are decreased maternal efforts during the second stage of labor.

 

Option B. Heart disease: Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction. However, it may influence the choice of delivery method to minimize maternal stress.

 

Option D. Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm: While full cervical dilation (10 cm) is ideal for vacuum extraction, it is a relative contraindication rather than an absolute one. In urgent situations where cesarean section is not feasible, vacuum extraction might still be considered even if the cervix is not fully dilated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absolute Contraindication of Ventouse:

 

  • Preterm
  • Face presentation
  • After coming head of the breech
  • IUD

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium levels
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with calcification. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level

 

In this case, the presence of granulomatous inflammation with calcification in the cervical lymph nodes is indicative of dystrophic calcification. Dystrophic calcification occurs in damaged or degenerating tissues, often associated with chronic inflammation or necrosis, while the serum calcium levels remain normal. This type of calcification is a localized process and doesn't require systemic calcium metabolism disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level: Incorrect. Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues due to hypercalcemia, which is not present in this case.

 

Option C. Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium levels: Incorrect. While metastatic calcification does involve increased serum calcium levels, the scenario described (granulomatous inflammation in lymph nodes) is more consistent with dystrophic calcification.

 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level: Incorrect. Dystrophic calcification occurs with normal serum calcium levels. Increased serum calcium is not a feature of dystrophic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatous inflammation with calcification in tissues, particularly in the context of chronic inflammation or tissue damage, is characteristic of dystrophic calcification, which occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

questions.text: For how many days must a person be unable to engage in their ordinary pursuits for an injury to be classified as grievous? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 20 days

 

Explanation:


This is an old question. As per old laws an injury is classified as grievous hurt  if it causes the sufferer to be unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of 20 days. Now the duration is decreased to 15 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 days - This duration is insufficient to classify an injury as grievous hurt. The law specifically requires a 20-day period of inability to follow ordinary pursuits.

 

Option C. 30 days - This duration exceeds the requirement specified in the IPC. While an injury causing disability for 30 days would certainly qualify as grievous, the legal threshold is set at 20 days.

 

Option D. 40 days - This duration also exceeds the requirement specified in the IPC. The legal threshold is set at 20 days.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For an injury to be classified as grievous hurt based on inability to follow ordinary pursuits, the disability must persist for a period of 15 days (earlier it was 20 days)

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IVIG

 

  • The constellation of symptoms described (fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling skin) is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. IVIG is a key component of the treatment for Kawasaki disease to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspirin: This is also a crucial part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease. Aspirin is used in Kawasaki disease to reduce inflammation and the risk of blood clot formation. However, it is often used in conjunction with IVIG.

 

Option C. Plenty of fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, fluid administration alone is not the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease. The use of IVIG and aspirin is more specific to address the underlying inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are antibiotics and are not the appropriate treatment for Kawasaki disease, which is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Fever + 4 out of 5 below = Classic Kawasaki

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest time when triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining can detect changes after a myocardial infarction? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2-3 hours

 

Triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining is used for the gross assessment of myocardial infarction. TTC reacts with the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) enzyme present in viable cardiac myocytes, producing a brick-red color in normal, viable myocardium. In infarcted areas, where the LDH enzyme has leaked out of damaged cells into the bloodstream, the tissue remains unstained (pale or white). This change can be detected as early as 2-3 hours after infarction, making it one of the earliest gross diagnostic methods for myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. By 6-12 hours, TTC staining would already show clear evidence of infarction. This timeframe is too late to be considered the earliest time for detection using TTC staining.

 

Option C. 12-24 hours: Incorrect. At this stage, myocardial infarction would show extensive changes on TTC staining, with well-defined areas of pallor representing infarcted tissue. This is well beyond the earliest detection time.

 

Option D. After 24 hours: Incorrect. This represents a late stage in the evolution of myocardial infarction, when multiple other changes including coagulative necrosis and inflammatory cell infiltration are occurring. TTC staining can detect changes much earlier than this timeframe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) staining can detect myocardial infarction changes as early as 2-3 hours post-infarction by identifying areas where LDH enzyme has leaked from damaged cardiac cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with persistent weight loss, night sweats, and productive cough for the past two months. Which medium is most appropriate for isolating the causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) based on:

 

  • Classic symptoms: persistent weight loss, night sweats, productive cough
  • Risk factor: diabetes mellitus (immunocompromised state)
  • Duration: symptoms lasting for two months (chronic course)

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative organism, requires special culture media because:

 

  • It does not grow on ordinary culture media
  • It is a slow-growing organism requiring enriched media
  • It needs specific nutrients and pH conditions for growth

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the gold standard for TB culture because:

 

  • It is an egg-based enriched medium containing glycerol and asparagine
  • Provides optimal nutrients for mycobacterial growth
  • Contains malachite green that inhibits other bacteria
  • Allows for characteristic colony formation (rough, buff-colored colonies)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler serum slope (LSS):

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option B. MacConkey agar:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Option C. Tinsdale medium:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used specifically for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation as it allows the formation of characteristic black colonies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard culture medium for isolating Mycobacterium tuberculosis from clinical specimens, as it provides the necessary enriched environment and selective conditions for optimal growth of this slow-growing organism.

 

 

CULTURE CHARACTERISTICS OF MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS

questions.text: Complete heart block in Neonatal Lupus is associated with which maternal autoantibodies? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anti-Ro 

 

Explanation: 

 

Complete congenital heart block in neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) is strongly associated with maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. These autoantibodies cross the placenta during pregnancy and can affect the developing fetal cardiac conduction system, particularly the atrioventricular (AV) node. The maternal anti-Ro antibodies can cause inflammation and subsequent fibrosis of the fetal cardiac conduction system, resulting in complete heart block. The risk of developing congenital heart block is approximately 2% in anti-Ro positive mothers, but increases to about 15-20% if there is a previous child with neonatal lupus. Anti-La (SSB) antibodies often coexist with anti-Ro and may increase the risk.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-RNP - Incorrect. While anti-RNP antibodies are found in mothers with mixed connective tissue disease and SLE, they are not specifically associated with congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Option C. Anti-ds-DNA - Incorrect. Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus in mothers but are not the primary antibodies associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option D. Anti-Sm - Incorrect. Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE diagnosis in mothers but are not specifically linked to congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are specifically associated with congenital complete heart block in neonatal lupus, requiring careful monitoring of the fetal heart rate during pregnancy in anti-Ro positive mothers, especially those with a previous affected child.

questions.text:
Which of the following about the enteric nervous regulation system is false? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers
  2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord
  3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve
  4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

The enteric nervous system (ENS) is often referred to as the "brain of the GIT". This complex network of neurons can function autonomously but also communicates with the central nervous system.

 

3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve: This is FALSE. While the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) does provide afferent innervation to the GIT, it is not the only source. Both the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) and sympathetic nerves provide afferent innervation to the GIT. 

 

4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria: This is FALSE. The myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the muscularis, not in the lamina propria which is part of the mucosa. 

 

Correct statements: 

 

1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers: This is TRUE. Interstitial cells of Cajal serve as pacemaker cells in the gastrointestinal tract. They produce Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER), which is defined as cyclic fluctuations in the resting membrane potential ranging from -40 to -60 mV. These cells are critical in establishing the intrinsic electrical rhythmicity of the GIT.

 

2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord: This is TRUE. The enteric nervous system is capable of functioning independently of the brain and spinal cord. The enteric nervous system is the "brain of GIT," and enteric nervous system connects with the autonomic nervous system, it can work independently through its own neural circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enteric nervous system is anatomically organized into two major plexuses - the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus located between longitudinal and circular muscle layers that controls motility, and the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus that regulates secretion. The enteric nervous system receives dual innervation from both sympathetic and parasympathetic (vagal) sources while maintaining the ability to function independently.

questions.text: A farmer had a lesion on his shoulder. Histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

The histopathological image provided shows features consistent with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The key characteristics that support this diagnosis are the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

 

Keratin pearls are concentric, whorl-like structures composed of keratinized cells, which are a hallmark of well-differentiated SCC. The presence of keratin indicates that the tumor cells are undergoing a process of keratinization, which is a characteristic feature of squamous epithelium. In the image, the pink, circular structures with a laminated appearance are keratin pearls.

 

Intercellular bridges, also known as desmosomes, are specialized cell junctions that connect adjacent squamous epithelial cells. These bridges help maintain the structural integrity of the epithelium and are visible as small, spiky projections between the tumor cells in the image.

 

The occupation of the patient (farmer) is also relevant, as prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight is a major risk factor for the development of SCC, particularly on sun-exposed areas like the shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is another type of skin cancer that arises from the basal layer of the epidermis. However, BCC typically lacks keratinization and the formation of keratin pearls, which are seen in this image.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus. Histologically, it is characterized by the presence of molluscum bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions within the keratinocytes. These features are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Verrucous carcinoma: Verrucous carcinoma is a rare, low-grade variant of SCC that typically presents as a warty, exophytic growth. While it may show some keratinization, the classic keratin pearls and intercellular bridges seen in this image are more suggestive of conventional SCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges in a skin biopsy is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in a patient with a history of prolonged sun exposure.

questions.text: Into which structure do the right suprarenal veins drain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Inferior vena cava


 

Explanation:

 

The right suprarenal vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava. This differs from the venous drainage pattern of the left suprarenal gland, which drains into the left renal vein. This asymmetric pattern of suprarenal venous drainage follows the general principle of asymmetry in venous drainage seen in other retroperitoneal structures, where right-sided vessels often connect directly to the inferior vena cava while left-sided vessels join via intermediate veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right renal vein - This is incorrect as the right suprarenal vein bypasses the right renal vein and drains directly into the inferior vena cava. Only the left suprarenal vein drains into its corresponding renal vein.

 

Option C. Left renal vein - This is incorrect for the right suprarenal vein. The left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, but the right suprarenal vein has a different drainage pattern.

 

Option D. Accessory Hemiazygos vein - This is incorrect as the accessory hemiazygos vein is part of the thoracic venous system that drains into the azygos vein, not a recipient of suprarenal venous drainage.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The right suprarenal vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava, while the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein - an important example of asymmetric venous drainage in retroperitoneal structures.

questions.text: The trans-inguinal descent of the testes occurs around: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C.  28 weeks

 

Explanation

 

The testes initially develop in the lumbar region of the posterior abdominal wall and undergo a gradual descent to the scrotum. This descent follows a specific timeline: the testes reach the iliac fossa during the 3rd month and remain at the deep inguinal ring until the 7th month of intrauterine life. The trans-inguinal descent (passage through the inguinal canal) occurs during the 7th month, which corresponds to approximately 28 weeks of gestation. By the end of the 8th month, the testes have normally completed their descent and are positioned in the scrotum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. 8 weeks: At this early stage (2nd month), the testes are still in their initial position in the lumbar region.
  • Option B. 12 weeks: By the 3rd month, the testes have only reached the iliac fossa and have not yet approached the inguinal canal.
  • Option D. 33 weeks: By this time (late 8th month), the testes would have already completed their trans-inguinal descent and would be positioned in the scrotum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular descent follows a precise timeline: lumbar region (origin) → iliac fossa (3rd month) → deep inguinal ring (until 7th month) → trans-inguinal passage (7th month/28 weeks) → scrotal position (by 8th month).

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Endotracheal intubation
B. Chest X-ray
C. Plain CT
D. ICD insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

 

The primary survey in trauma is a critical initial assessment conducted to identify and manage life-threatening conditions. It follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure). The focus is on stabilizing the patient, and only essential interventions are performed during this phase.

 

Option A. Endotracheal Intubation: This is part of airway management in an unstable trauma patient. If the airway is compromised or there is a risk of airway obstruction, endotracheal (ET) intubation is performed immediately to secure the airway.

 

Option B. Chest X-ray: Although a chest X-ray is considered an adjunct to the primary survey, it is often done bedside in the trauma room as part of the initial assessment of breathing and circulation. It is particularly useful for identifying conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or other thoracic injuries that require immediate attention.

 

Option D. ICD Insertion: Intercostal Drain (ICD) insertion is a bedside procedure that can be part of the primary survey if there is a massive pneumothorax or hemothorax. In cases of tension pneumothorax, an immediate needle decompression is performed, followed by ICD insertion, which is critical for patient survival.

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Plain CT: This is not included in the primary survey. CT scans are generally reserved for stable patients as they require the patient to be transported to the radiology department, which is not feasible or safe in an unstable trauma patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

choices.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the hospital with an episode of acute cholecystitis. Symptoms are controlled with medical management. On ultrasound, there is a solitary gallstone of 1.5 cm. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

 

Explanation:

 

For acute cholecystitis that has responded to medical management, the current best practice is early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission. The Tokyo guidelines recommend early cholecystectomy within 5-7 days for mild cases (Tokyo I). For this 45-year-old patient whose symptoms are controlled with medical management, proceeding with laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list (during the same admission) is the optimal approach, as it reduces the risk of recurrent attacks while operating when inflammation has started to resolve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and regular follow-up - This is inappropriate for a patient who has already experienced acute cholecystitis. Once symptomatic complications occur, definitive surgical management is required to prevent recurrent attacks, which can be more severe and lead to additional complications.

 

Option B. Elective cholecystectomy after inflammation subsides - This approach represents delayed surgery scheduled weeks to months after discharge, which is now considered an outdated practice. It increases the risk of recurrent episodes during the waiting period and can lead to more difficult surgery due to scarring and adhesions.

 

Option D. Urgent open cholecystectomy - Open cholecystectomy is not the first-line approach unless laparoscopic surgery is contraindicated. For mild to moderate cases that have been medically stabilized, there is no indication for urgent open surgery, as laparoscopic approach offers less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and faster recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute cholecystitis responsive to medical management, early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission (on the next available list) is the standard of care, offering the best balance between allowing initial inflammation to subside while preventing recurrent attacks.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
